channel.title: Articles • Hrvoje Šimić
channel.description: A collection of long form articles by Hrvoje Šimić

item.title: Build aspirins for friends
item.description: As a developer, I easily get carried away building new things. Side projects are fun for me, especially when they are useful. In fact, I actively avoid programming that is useful only as a learning exercise, like puzzles and tests. Instead of that, I try to build useful things.

item.title: Writing a lot is not enough
item.description: I've published an article or a book review every week for the past six months. But is publishing consistently the right thing to do to get better at writing?

item.title: Why you should keep a learning journal
item.description: I've had a learning journal since 2011, but only recently have I realized the main benefit from it: it makes me learn more by paying more attention to bugs.

item.title: My experience with switching apps for personal knowledge management
item.description: Personal knowledge management (PKM) is the best thing I discovered in 2019. I've since tried a couple of different approaches and too many (six) apps. In this article, I would like to share everything I've learned about it over that period.

item.title: When magic works against you
item.description: When I first encountered this concern in the Rails app that I was working on, I was initially impressed. It felt like magic. Like a cool trick to avoid unnecessary complexity.

item.title: The importance of detachment
item.description: All my previous side projects flopped because of this. I looked at them from the perspective of a creator. I was stuck in that role. I didn’t have the experience of all the other people that were supposed to use the end product.

item.title: The overreaction paradox
item.description: My bike got stolen a while back. It happened because I got lazy carrying my bike up the stairs and left it in the much less secure basement. I thought that taking it up the stairs is not worth it. Nothing will happen. No one will steal a bike from my building since it hasn't happened to any of my neighbors.

item.title: Write for yourself
item.description: There’s a tension that you’ll discover if you start publishing articles. A tension between writing what the world wants from you and what you want to write about.

item.title: Beware of programming puzzles
item.description: The most common piece of advice you'll receive if you want to learn programming is that you should do programming to learn it. While this is well-meaning advice, since doing programming is better than reading about it, it's incomplete.

item.title: Knowing the port one is sailing to
item.description: If one does not know to which port one is sailing, no wind is favorable.
